They may direct a person not to enter the area, to leave it, or to move from one place to another within it, and enter and search premises or a means of transport for the purposes of directing any person found therein to leave the area. It will also be possible for members to make it a condition of entry that a person or vehicle be searched for any dangerous object.

Defence Force members will be authorised to make safe or prevent from being used any dangerous object seized under these provisions and, if practicable, will be required to issue a receipt for it. If it is suspected to have been used in the commission of an offence, then it must be given to a police officer; if not, then it must be returned to the owner. Someone who is suspected of having used a dangerous object to commit an offence may be detained and handed over to the police. In detaining such persons, necessary force may be used and, if practicable, the person must be advised of the nature of the offence unless this is clear in the circumstances.

When exercising the authorities set out in division 3 it will be an offence for a Defence Force member not to wear uniform and identification attached to the front of the uniform, except where the absence of identification is caused by the act of someone else. It will also be an offence to obstruct a member performing these duties. If a member fails to comply with any obligation in relation to the exercise of these authorities then they will be taken not to have been entitled to exercise them.

The bill has no effect on uses or authorities of the Defence Force under other legislation and powers such as customs, immigration and fisheries legislation. The bill also preserves the current prohibition set out in section 51 of the Defence Act regarding the use of Defence Force elements in connection with industrial disputes.

The bill attempts to provide for the changing nature of the terrorist threat, a threat that was not within contemplation when the Defence Act and its regulations were drafted almost 100 years ago. Today we must be on our guard against not only deadly military style conventional weapons but also the so-called weapons of mass destruction. When the sarin gas device was triggered in Tokyo the lack of control and capability at the scene resulted in around 5,000 people fanning out around the city to contaminate other persons and medical facilities. While there is no expectation that we will ever confront such a threat it would be irresponsible not to be prepared for it. It is scenarios such as this that the division 3 provisions were designed to address.

Whilst it is the government's intention to bring this bill into effect prior to the Olympics, it should be viewed in the wider context of our counter-terrorist preparedness and in that context it should also form part of our long-term deterrence posture. Through these measures international terrorists will know that we are serious and we are prepared.

The bill provides for the limited use of the Defence Force in the last resort where there is a significant threat to public safety or to deal with an armed terrorist attack where the resources or capability of a state or territory may not be adequate. It does so without derogation from our cherished standards of justice and due process of the law. It provides safeguards and accountability. The tasks and authorities of the Defence Force are clearly spelled out so that both the public and the Defence Force know exactly what to expect. This also provides a sound basis upon which the Defence Force can train so that their responses and actions will be measured and appropriate. The bill does not interfere with the jurisdiction of the courts to supervise the actions of the Defence Force. Members of the Defence Force remain accountable for their decisions to use force and the lawfulness of their actions. However, the bill does provide Defence Force members with better protection for the action they may reasonably take.

Finally this bill enshrines fundamental democratic principles in the call-out process as opposed to the current inadequate legislative framework and emphasises and provides for the primacy of civilian control. It is a bill which is long overdue and I commend it to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.
Leave granted for debate to continue forthwith.

talk.start.para: âAs the parliamentary secretary has indicated, the Defence Legislation Amendment (Aid to Civilian Authorities) Bill 2000 will amend the Defence Act 1903 to bring up to date the framework for the call-out of the Defence Force in security emergencies. The bill will provide a proper basis for emergency use of the Defence Force as a last resort. Whilst the parliamentary secretary has indicated that this particular amendment to the legislation is long overdue, I think it is important that we do recognise that the catalyst for its being considered at this time is the Olympic Games and the preparedness that we need to have for the security of the people of Sydney and those people who are coming to Sydney as athletes, officials and guests.

speech.para: We all recognise that in this world today, unfortunately, there are still terrorist groups that would like nothing better than to highlight their ability to cause mayhem, death and destruction by targeting a specific world event. There is certainly not going to be a larger world event this year, as far as Australia is concerned, than the Olympic Games in Sydney in September. It is therefore important, as suggested by the parliamentary secretary and by the government, that the Australian Defence Force play a role in whatever security measures may be required and that nothing is left to chance. It is important, for the fundamental regime that governs the way in which that Defence Force can participate as part of a call-out to protect Australians and Australia's interests and people who are visiting this country, that we have that framework in place.

The impetus for the examination of the Defence Legislation Amendment (Aid to Civilian Authorities) Bill 2000 was the Hilton bombing at the time of the Commonwealth Heads of Government regional meetings in 1978, which led to the call-out of significant numbers of the Defence Force to secure the town of Bowral. Following this event, a protective security review was instituted, headed by the then Justice Hope, who went on to become the Chancellor of the University of Wollongong, and who I regarded as a very close friend. We miss him dearly.

In this respect, the Hope report highlighted the unsatisfactory state of the call-out framework, particularly from the point of view of the vagueness of the authority and expectations of the Defence Force's accountability and process. While there are two types of potential call-out, either Commonwealth initiated or following Commonwealth agreement to call out upon the request of a state, the current legislation deals with call-out only in response to a state request. The present legislative framework does not provide for sufficient parliamentary accountability to prevent any perceived misuse of the Defence Force. There needs to be provision for both safeguards in the exercise of such authority and also accountability for the actions of individuals as well as governments.

Our expectations for the use of the Defence Force have been distilled over the years since the 1978 national anti-terrorist plan, which is now in its sixth edition. This plan was formulated in coordination with all those agenciesâstate, territory and Commonwealthâwhich were involved in the counter-terrorist response. Under the plan, the Defence Force will be called out only as a last resort, where the resources of a state or territory are not sufficient to provide the best resolution of a situation. The plan provides for the use of specialised assault equipment and skills to deal with the more sophisticated threats in order to recover hostages, aircraft, ships, vehicles, offshore oil and gas installations and buildings. They may also be asked to perform tasks related to terrorist threats, such as providing cordons, evacuations, seizing and making safe dangerous items and building search. Such support might be required in a situation involving a chemical, biological or radiological device in order to evacuate and secure a large area.

The Defence Legislation Amendment (Aid to Civilian Authorities) Bill 2000 amends the Defence Act 1903 by repealing the first paragraph of section 51 and adding a new part. It also repeals the related Australian military and airforce regulations. Call-out will be initiated to protect Commonwealth interests or on the application of a state or territory to protect that state or territory from domestic violence. Call-out will occur only if the Prime Minister, the Minister for Defence and the Attorney-General agree that a state or territory is not able or is unlikely to be able to protect a Commonwealth interest or itself against the domestic violence. An order of the Governor-General would authorise the Minister for Defence to use the Defence Force for the purposes set out in the order. The Chief of the Defence Force must ensure that the Defence Force, while remaining under his command at all times, assist and cooperate with the police force of the state and territory. Members of the Defence Force will be able to exercise such authority only as is specified in the order from within the prescribed authorities set out in the act. As far as it is practicable, members of the Defence Force will not be able to exercise these authorities unless requested to perform a task by the police of the state or territory.

As was indicated by the parliamentary secretary, there are all sorts of limitations placed on the way in which those orders can in fact be struck. There is a 20-day limitation, for example, under a number of other sections and divisions of the amendment being proposed. There are also inclusions for tasks associated with public safety, terrorist assault roles, the way in which the authorisation can be handled and so on. As I said in my introductory remarks, this legislation sets out and firms up a process that, I guess, has sometimes been taken for granted. It also, of course, provides the opportunity for scrutiny of the way in which something like this may be used by this parliament to ensure that it is done in the appropriate way. Quite obviously, as I said, for all good strong commonsense legal reasons, you will get written into this legislation, as it is proposed and as the parliamentary secretary noted, the need for things like handing over receipts if things are taken during the course of a search and so on. There may be a good legal reason, but I have to say that, in terms of practical implementation, it would be a bit hard if you are leading an assault on someone who might be trying to do maximum harm to the maximum number of people at the Sydney Olympics to say as you are going out the door, `By the way, here's the receipt for your nuclear device' or `Here's the receipt for your chemical weapon'âa bit odd; but, nevertheless, I understand the reasons why that is included within the bill.

I would like to indicate that Labor will not be opposing the legislation in the House. We recognise that section 51 of the Defence Act does require amendment so that more appropriate provisions and processes can be put in place with regard to the use of the Australian Defence Force personnel in emergency law enforcement roles. Of course, we have seen that this is something that our Australian Defence Force has a capability of doingâin peacekeeping and policing operations. In some cases we have also seen the Australian Federal Police in unarmed situations. This type of role is appropriate for the Australian Defence Force, and its use in those very limited circumstances is appropriate, but with the appropriate caveats, controls and mechanisms that this legislation seeks to provide.

As I mentioned earlier, the report prepared by Justice Hope in his Protective Security Review does assistâdespite being done in 1979âin highlighting some of the deficiencies with the current legislation. However, as I said earlier, I accept that it is the Olympics that is the driver for the changes that are being brought in in respect of the timing of this bill. As I am sure other members of this House know, the Australian Defence Force has been training for any potential difficulties that might arise at the Olympics. Operation Gold is the tag name that is given to that process. I well recall that there were some complaints from people about the use of Black Hawk helicopters and our trained SAS people flying over Homebush to participate at night in an antiterrorist training exercise. But for a few short hours at night, I am sure they will sleep much better knowing that if troops were required in the real thing that training will stand them in good stead. We understand the professionalism that people like Air Vice Marshal Brett Espeland and others, who are coordinating the role of the Australian Defence Force in the security of the Olympics, will bring to that task. We certainly hope that it is something that is not required during the Olympics. We hope that the Olympics in Sydney turn out to be the showcase for Sydney and Australia that it is hoped it will be. We are, however, comforted in the knowledge that, through the training for Operation Gold, the Australian defence personnel across the three services will have a very real role that they can play should that need arise.

That said, I think it is also important that we indicate and put on the record that the opposition will not be pressured into passing legislation if we are not completely confident about its merits and its value. But we are happy to facilitate as speedy a passage as possible for the legislation through the House of Representatives and, I would hope, also through the Senate. It is important to point out that, if passed, this bill will not give the ADF any greater powers than it has at the moment through section 51 of the Defence Act. I think that is probably the most critical thing in this debate. This legislation, as it stands now, gives the ADF the sorts of powers that we are seeking to amplify and specify in the legislation and imposes some processes and procedures to be followed. It also provides for the appropriate protection for ADF personnel if and when they are ever used under the provision of this act.

As I said a little earlier, regrettably, in this world of constant change and in this world where you have people with plenty of money to spend on all sorts of fanatical causes, we do have circumstances in which there are terrorist activities and attempts to bring maximum harm to the maximum number of people in order to maximise the publicity that those particular individuals or organisations get. We still have the ongoing drama in Fiji, which is a terrorist activity. We still have ongoing problems in the southern Philippines, where a separatist Muslim organisation has kidnapped tourists from neighbouring Malaysia and is still holding many of those people hostage to try to push for a separate Muslim state to be created in the Philippines, which of course is a largely Catholic country. We still have, from time to time, bombings of major buildings. There were the Oklahoma bombing and the bombing of the World Trade Centre in New York. All of this is geared towards some fanatical organisation trying to maximise publicity for its particular cause. I think it is important, therefore, that this legislation spell out how we in Australia treat seriously the call-out provisions that exist already but that may be required during the course of such a major event as the Sydney Olympics. It is important that we indicate how seriously we as a parliament and as a nation take the need to ensure that every aspect of this aid to civilian authorities bill, which is proposing these amendments, provides appropriate protection for ADF personnel if and when they are called and that the processes and procedures followed are correct and can be ticked off on.

Also, it is appropriate that I thank both the Minister for Defence and the Attorney-General for providing me and the shadow Attorney-General, my good friend the honourable member for Barton, and indeed the Leader of the Opposition, with briefings on the bill prior to its introduction. It is important that a spirit of bipartisanship be exhibited in this place on something as important as this, and that has been the case in the briefings that we had with the relevant ministers and their staff. I would also readily acknowledge that the government has already taken on board most of the recommendations that the Labor opposition suggested to it at those briefings, and these have been reflected in the bill. My colleague the member for Barton will probably make some comment on the provisions which have been picked up by the government. I think that demonstrates how, on something as important as this, both sides of politics can work for the common good. In this case, the common good is the protection of Sydney during the course of the Olympics. But at some future time, again when terrorist activity may be thought likely to occur, the Australian Defence Force can play a legitimate role in assisting state and territory governments and police forces in taking whatever steps are necessary to ensure that that does not occur.

I would like to point out at this stage that there are still some reservations that the opposition has with regard to certain parts of the bill. It will not be a surprise to the government, because we have already signalled our intention here, that Labor will move to have the bill referred to an appropriate legislation committee in the Senate for examination. What we do not believe is necessary is some long drawn out discussion within that legislation committee in the Senate, but I do think it is important that the ADF and others in the Australian community have an opportunity to put some submissions to that particular committee on one or two of the elements here that are still of concern to us.

One of the major sticking points that we would like the government to address is that surrounding the authorising ministers. As it stands at the moment, the Prime Minister, the Attorney-General and the Minister for Defence are the authorising ministers, but the bill allows for them to delegate or nominate an extra minister if the circumstances require it. Frankly, I do not know that there is a need for that. I think, when we are talking about something as critically important as authorising the use of the Australian Defence Force for quelling domestic violenceâit is a quaint term, I know, but it refers to antiterrorist activity and so onâthat we have got it right with the Prime Minister, the Attorney-General and the Minister for Defence being the responsible ministers. To suggest that it may be delegated to someone else along that chain of command is inappropriate. They, at the end of the day, are three participating ministersâincluding the Prime Ministerâin the security committee of cabinet. They are the relevant ministers when it comes to something as critical as this, so they should be the three who take that responsibility.

In this day and age of communications, I find it extraordinary to think that, if one of those particular individuals were not readily available to make an authorisation, they could not be contacted. Mobile phone coverage around this country today is pretty good. We saw the shadow minister for industrial relations tapping away in here on his computer a moment ago. I am sure Minister Moore, the Attorney-General and the Prime Minister are up on their skills in that area as well, so it would not be difficult to get emails to them if necessary to get the appropriate authorisation.

The best way to deal with this, as I have already indicated, is to pass it speedily through this place. It is certainly not the intention of the opposition to hold up the bill's passage. We have three or four speakers on our side and there are probably a similar number on the government side, so we will get rid of it by question time today and off it will go to the Senate. We do think that it is necessary to have this inquiry into the bill by a Senate committee during the winter recess. It is appropriate that it then come back in the first sitting week in August for consideration. That is only six or seven weeks away. It could be passed by the Senate at that stage, hopefully with the suggestions that we have already flagged, which we feel are important. It would then become law and we would have in place some clear, concise, direct guidelines as an adjunct to section 51 of the Defence Act which specify the way in which the Australian Defence Force might be used in a call-out for domestic violence.

As I said earlier, and I will wind up on this, I think that the parameters that have been included in this build on the excellent work that was done initially by Justice Hope and on the excellent work that was done over the years by a whole series of attorneys-general. I know that in this respect Lionel Bowen looked at the way in which those policy parameters might in fact be put in place and they were implemented successively by Attorney-General Duffy and also justice ministers Tate and Kerr in Labor administrations.

At the end of the day what we should not get away from is the fact that the catalyst for this legislation coming forward to date is the Olympic Games. We will provideâcertainly with the support of both sides of this parliament and indeed, I would suggest, the whole of the parliamentâsupport for the ADF should that become necessary. Of course, we all hope it does not; we all hope that the security arrangements that are in place are appropriate, as they are at the moment. We certainly hope that the Olympic Games are the success that people in Australia believe they will be and should be.

There has been a lot of time, effort and, dare I say, money expended on the Olympics to ensure that it does showcase Sydney and Australia. However, it is important that we say to those dissident groups that might be around the world, should they decide that it is an appropriate venue to try to stir up some problems, that Australia is ready, and the men and women of the Australian Defence Force certainly are ready, to lend assistance to the police force in New South Wales in the event of such a contingency arising. As I say, though, we would hope that is not necessary. We wish this legislation a speedy passage through the parliament.

talk.start.para: âIt has been a long time since the Hilton Hotel bombing and the incident referred to by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage and the member for Cunningham in which defence forces were called out around the town of Bowral. It is okay for the opposition defence spokesman to roll the credits of all the former ALP defence ministers and attorneys-general, but what concerns me a little about where we are at today is the length of time that has elapsed since the events of the Hilton Hotel bombing and the CHOGM meeting and the fact that it is only at this late stage that we are getting down to this important bit of legislation. This is legislation that the parliamentary secretary referred to as `overdue'. I would certainly agree with that. I think it illustrates the necessity for the shake-up that is going on in the Defence Force, that what we need to do is ensure that we prioritise effectivelyâand I believe that this legislation, being overdue, should have been seen in this House long before now. In fact, I do not think it is correct for people in this place to talk about it purely in the context of the Olympics. The Olympics, of course, is a vital event, something that Australia looks forward to with a great deal of relish and that we must be absolutely prepared for. But this is not an Olympic bill: this is not a bill about doing something special for the Olympics; it is a bill that sets in place a set of protocols that have to be correct, appropriate and effective for the purposes of the correct running of our Defence Force and the good order of our society.

speech.para: I am pleased to hear the opposition spokesman speak of bipartisanship. It is good that the opposition will be facilitating the bill's rapid progress through the House and the Senate. I am glad that there has been a level of bipartisanship that has allowed for a briefing of the opposition about this. Without this bill you would have to wonder about the circumstances that personnel would find themselves in if they were involved in the kind of terrible activity that this bill contemplates. Without this bill you would have to wonder about the legal protection, for example, of military personnel who might be tied up in very serious events in which policy in relation to life and death may well be being made on the run. Earlier on the parliamentary secretary talked about the current position requiring bugle calls and things like that. I cannot believe that we are so archaic as to still have that within our system. We live in the 21st century and it is a real concern to me that for something as serious as this quaint term `domestic violence'âwhich is really about riots, serious public affray, danger, bombs and all these kinds of thingsâwe are that far behind in relation to governing legislation.

We would not want to find ourselves in a situation where, in the middle of a hostage drama, we are confronted by a constitutional crisis about who gives the orders. That is precisely what is going on today in Fiji. Who is the giving the orders over there? What we need is a simple layout of where and when responsibility shifts in a situation like this. I realise what both the parliamentary secretary and the opposition spokesman have said about the existing national antiterrorist plan and the fact that it has been through six generations. I cannot believe that we have a national antiterrorist plan that has gone through six generations and yet things such as those that are contemplated in this bill have not been cleaned up. I think we have put the cart before the horse, although it is a very important cart. Being able to rescue people, being able to deal with hostage situations and being able to deal with serious rioting and that sort of thing are things that we must have at our fingertips; they are an integral part of the management of good order.

I would like to refer to the procedures that apply. The Australian Defence Force may be called out under the Defence Legislation Amendment (Aid to Civilian Authorities) Bill 2000 if the Prime Minister, Attorney-General or the Minister for Defenceâwho are the authorising ministersâare each satisfied. The opposition spokesman said in his comments that he could not see why it would be contemplated that there would be the opportunity to defer responsibility to another minister. Mr Deputy Speaker, I will suggest to you that, if we are dealing with hostage situations, we have to be able to contemplate the possibility that maybe the defence minister himself will be a hostage in a situation like that. Every eventuality has to be covered. If there are eventualities that are not correctly covered and if the chain of command is not absolutely clearcut and watertight, this sort of situation can break down very quicklyâand by overseas experience we can see exactly what that means. As for the concerns of the opposition on this matter, I do not think that they have really given this the thought that is needed. There needs to be a clear chain of authority, and it is important that more than just one minister is required to sign off on this kind of activity. We have three, and we have the opportunity if there is not the three for there to be a replacement. That is important.

I have spoken about the first of the procedures. The second is that these three ministers must be satisfied that a state or territory is unlikely to be able, or is unable, to maintain order or to protect the Commonwealth interests or the state or territory concerned against domestic violence. They must also be satisfied that the ADF is needed to assist. Then, and only then, the Governor-General may make a written order directing the Chief of Defence Force to use the ADF for that purpose. Those procedures are important, well thought out and appropriate. I do not think that it serves us well after having waited since 1979, after a length of time during which this was contemplated by the Defence Force bureaucracy, for us now to go off to a legislation committee and to run around there for too great a period of time. I appreciate that the opposition would like to see it minimised, but I really wonder whether it is necessary to engage too much in overheated public discussion when we are getting advice about something as basic as this from the Defence Force and when what we want is effective military management of a serious situation.

As I have mentioned, the delays in this are of concern to me, and I think they are symptomatic of various problems we have seen in the Defence Force over the years. The situation in the Defence Force at the moment is that we are still endeavouring to clear up the problems that have confronted the government over the submarines, which the Department of Defence is yet to be able to bring effectively on line for the defence of our country. I do not think we would be in the position of having to contemplate this massive reorganisation of the defence forces in Australia today if we had not had debacles like that submarine exercise. We have seen a cost blow-out over that exercise which has increased the initial budget of $2.6 billion to about $5 billion, and all the way along there has been a series of obfuscations from the opposition about the whole submarine exercise. Quite honestly, today the defence of Australia is suffering as a result.

I would like to go back to some of the various parts of the bill. There are two divisions of power within the bill that I think are important to note. They are set out in divisions 2 and 3 within the bill. The first one enables the kind of activity to recapture premises, to free hostages, to detain people, to evacuate an area and to search for and seize a dangerous thing. That, of course, is something that the national antiterrorist plan has been working on for some time, and I am sure that when it comes down to the nuts and bolts of administering such a thing the antiterrorist plan is going to be effective after six generations.

In relation to division 3, however, we come into some different areas. This division is in relation to calling out the Defence Force for policing activities. There would be difficulties in simply assigning police powers to Defence Force members. Unlike New Zealand, Australia has different states within which police have different powers. It is too incredible to imagine that we could require our Defence Force personnel to become expert in the various levels of police responsibility that apply in each one of those statesâit would be an unmanageable situation. I believe this bill comes up with an effective answer to that: basically, it sets out the situation where orders will be given and where people will act on those orders. It is not a matter of having blanket powers that can be enacted; it is a matter of addressing the situation that arises. For example, the bill sets aside the opportunity to establish a general or designated security area. Within that area, the defence forces are able to cordon off areas where they might want to deal with some dangerous thing such as a bomb, a chemical weapon or something like that. They can also search transport vehicles and take that kind of action.

I have given an undertaking that I will be short in my remarks, so I will truncate them somewhat, particularly in relation to industrial disputes. In relation to section 51 of the Defence Act, which prohibits the use of the Reserve or emergency forces of the ADF in industrial disputes, I think the people of Australia will be pleased to know that the status quo is to be maintained. That is appropriate. We are not setting out to change the boundaries of what is or is not appropriate practice, particularly when we come from a long history of ascertaining what is acceptable and appropriate in those sorts of circumstances. The existing situation has been retained, and we are setting out the flow of command that facilitates that activity.

Something else that members should note is that it is only possible for reserves to be called out in situations when the permanent force of the Defence Force is insufficient to accomplish what is required to be done. Defence Force members in this activity are required only to use reasonable force. Once an activity is complete, the minister is required to report to parliament within seven days. I commend the bill to the House. I believe it is appropriate, and I welcome it because I believe it is long overdue.

talk.start.para: âI think it is fair to say that in modern-day Australia the greatest threat to Australians is not from foreign invasion of 15,000 troops but rather 15 individuals coming into Australia to undertake terrorist activities, whether that is using sophisticated weaponry, chemicals, gas or even biological weapons. We must be alive to that possibility. It is not one that we think is likely, but we would be in neglect of our responsibility to the Australian people if we did not properly equip our defence forces to handle that task.

speech.para: It has to be said that the Defence Legislation Amendment (Aid to Civilian Authorities) Bill 2000 is not giving the defence forces any powers that they do not already have but it is providing for four factors. Firstly, it is going to set the parameters for the conduct of the defence forces when they are called out in a situation of a domestic emergency. Secondly, it will provide a detailed regime of accountability, and that is vitally important. Thirdly, it will form part of our deterrence insofar as anyone contemplating this sort of terrorist activity in Australia would be on notice, if you like, as to the response that that activity would receive. The fourth issue where this bill is very relevant is in the area of training. It will certainly be of assistance to our defence forces if they know what those issues are and the parameters involved in the conduct, and they can properly train to coordinate and cooperate with state police forces in undertaking their duties.

Much has been said in the debate earlier regarding the quaint expression `domestic violence'. It is in fact an important expression. It is contained in section 119 of the Constitution. That section provides:

quote.para: The Commonwealth shall protect every State against invasion and, on application of the Executive Government of the State, against domestic violence.

speech.para: That has been interpreted to mean significant violence, not violence in a household. In addition to that, while section 119 refers to call-out to assist states at the request of states, the High Court has held in The King v. Sharkey that the power of the Commonwealth also extends to defending Commonwealth interests. In the judgment, reference is made to what is a famous quote, in this area at least, by the authors Quick and Garran on the constitutional law. It is probably worth referring to that quote because it does set out the interaction between the two issues of this power. One is to protect the interests of the state when requested by the states, and the other is the power that the Commonwealth has to protect the interests of the Commonwealth. The authors say:

quote.para: The maintenance of order in a State is primarily the concern of the State, for which the police powers of the State are ordinarily adequate. But even if the State is unable to cope with domestic violence, the Federal Government has no right to intervene, for the protection of the State or its citizens, unless called upon by the State Executive. If, however, domestic violence within a State is of such a character as to interfere with the operations of the Federal Government, or with the rights and privileges of federal citizenship, the Federal Government may clearly, without a summons from the State, interfere to restore order.

speech.para: They are the two heads of power, and it is important to note that section 51, which this bill will repeal, refers to only one aspect of power, and that is the aspect in respect of the call-out at the request of the states. There is clearly a broader spectrum to have in mind. So it is important for people to realise when they consider this bill that it is not giving additional powers to the Commonwealth but rather is codifying and clarifying those powers.

It is also necessary, when you are looking at this bill, to compare it with what exists currently. A number of speakers have spoken on the quaint powers that exist in the Australian Military Regulations, and in particular part 5âthe Duties In Aid of the Civil Power During Domestic Violence. They are contained in regulations 398 through to 415. Those regulations were made under the Defence Act, which we are amending. There is no doubt that those regulations are based on common law as it existed in the 18th century. Many members of the House would have heard the expression `I'm going to read the riot act'. That is where that expression comes from. It is in regulation 407, which provides that a magistrate must accompany the defence forces and the role of a magistrate is to `read the Riot Act' before the defence forces go into the area. I understand that there is a necessity to blow a bugle before that occurs. That is quite inappropriate to modern risks that we would confront by way of terrorist activity. As Senator Durack previously said in response to the Hope report, which other speakers have commented on:

quote.para: Part 5 of the Australian Military Regulations and Part IX of the Air Force Regulations are directed to a riot situation of a kind more to be expected in 18th century England than in Australia in the present day. By contrast, these regulations make no specific provisions for acts of violence by individuals or small groups of persons, possibly armed with highly effective weapons.

speech.para: That is undoubtedly correct. All members of the House are cooperating to bring our laws up to date. I think the previous speaker, the member for Blair, suggested some neglect on the part of the military in respect of this issue, and I think that is unfair. The neglect has not been on the part of military at all; for a long time they have wanted these matters clarified. The neglect has more relevantly been at a legislative level in not clarifying the powers more precisely.

As previous speakers have indicated, the impetus for these amendments came in 1978 following the Hope commission and that followed the utilisation of the defence forces in Bowral to provide protection to foreign officials following the Hilton bombing in 1978. The use of the defence forces in those circumstances involved some controversy. The public will always be apprehensive when they see the defence forces used in any number in that sort of situation. The inquiry into the use of the defence forces in that particular situation and generally showed just how inadequate the current framework isâhence the recommendations to address it.

As I have indicated, there are two types of call-out: one call out to protect the interests of the Commonwealth; the other when the states have requested it. The present legislation deals only with the second. Also, the current legislative framework does not provide for sufficient parliamentary accountability. So anyone examining this bill must, if they are doing fairness to it, factor in as a vitally important component that for the first time there will be a need to report to parliament regarding the use of the defence forces in these circumstances. There is also going to be a number of safeguards which will apply. Those safeguards include defining more readily the circumstances in which defence forces are going to be required.

It must be recognised that there may well be circumstances where it will be only the Australian defence forces that are properly equipped with specialised assault equipment and skills to deal with more sophisticated security threats in order to recover hostages, aircraft, ships, vehicles, offshore and gas installations, and buildings. They may also be required to provide cordons in domestic violence situations, to assist in the evacuation, seizing and making safe dangerous items and undertaking searches of buildings. We cannot ignore the possibility of chemical, biological or even radioactive devices being used in terrorist activities and the need to urgently evacuate and secure large areas.

The protections that are built into the legislation will include that the Chief of Defence Force must ensure that the Defence Force, while remaining under his command at all times, must assist and cooperate with the police force of the state. It is important to appreciate that the Defence Force will be able to exercise only such authority as is specified in the order from within the prescribed authorities set out in the act. As far as is practicable, members of the Defence Force will not be able to exercise these authorities unless requested to perform a task by the police of a state or territory. The other protections involved are that the order itself must state the nature of the Commonwealth interest threatened or the domestic violence occurring in the state. It must be clearly specified; it cannot be just a general utilisation of the defence forces in anticipation, for instance, that there could be an event during the period of the Olympic Games. There would have to be an actual threat or an actual violent incident for this legislation to be enacted.

The order ceases after 20 days, if not revoked earlier by the relevant ministers, who are the Prime Minister, the Minister for Defence and the Attorney-General. The Minister for Defence must, as soon as practicable and within seven days, table a copy of the order or orders and any declarations and report on the use of the Defence Force. The Defence Force counter-terrorist assault role will be provided for in division 2 of the new part being inserted into the Defence Act. That will really clarify the circumstances in which the defence forces are able to use necessary and reasonable force in the important tasks that may be required of them, such as rescuing hostages and recapturing premises, including private property.

In relation to tasks associated with public safety generally, division 3 is important. It provides for the role of the military, in securing areas, that a declaration must, again by way of safeguards, specify the area, the reasons for the activity and the authorities that the Defence Force may exercise. Equally, in respect of search and entry, the authorisation must describe the premises, identify the member in charge, authorise that member and other search members to carry out the search, and authorise the seizure of items believed on reasonable grounds to be dangerous things. It will also authorise the search of persons in the vicinity, but only on the condition that there were reasonable grounds to believe that they possessed a dangerous thing or substance. It is important to realise that the power can be used only for the time that the authorisation remains in force which, in the case of that particular activity, cannot be for more than 24 hours.

It is also important to note, by way of a safeguard, that a copy of the authorisation has to be given to the occupier or the person representing them in that building. So it is not a situation where the military can come in completely unrestrained. Division 3 also introduces the concept of the designated area which the ministers may declare, but the safeguards in place are that that declaration must once again be advised to the public, including its specific boundaries.

Defence Force members will be authorised to make safe or prevent from being used any dangerous things seized under those provisions and, if practicable, as we have indicated, to provide a receipt. It has to be recognised that in many circumstances that will not be practicable, but their activities will nonetheless go unimpeded. If an item is suspected to have been used in the commission of an offence, then it must be given to a police officer. If not, it must be returned to the owner.

The other protections are that it will be an offence for a member of the Defence Force not to wear a uniform and identification attached to that uniform. If a member fails to comply with any obligation in relation to the exercise of these powers and authorities, they will be taken not to have been entitled to have exercised them. So there are very strict obligations on members of the Defence Force exercising these authorities. As the previous speaker mentioned, it is also important to realise that this bill will not apply to situations of industrial dispute. That is, the status quo currently set out in section 51 of the Defence Act will remain. Nothing is changed in that respect. That is important. It is also important for people looking at this particular issue to note that, as a result of negotiations with the opposition, the government will include in proposed section 51A, subsection 1, clause (a), an additional phrase which will place as the precondition on the exercise of these powers that domestic violence is occurring or is likely to occur in Australia. So the context of a mere industrial dispute would in any event not be likely to fall into that category of serious domestic violence for which these powers are designed.

There are a number of other safeguards built into the legislation which other speakers have spoken on. As has been constantly noted, it is important for people who are analysing this bill to note that no additional powers are being given to the defence forces. What is being done is to clarify the exercise of those powers to set a framework of accountability in place. That is in the interests of good law enforcement but also in the interests of the members of the defence forces themselves who will be required to exercise these powers. In short, the Commonwealth cannot simply act on a whim. It cannot act on the whim of a particular ministerâor even the Prime Ministerâwho has some particular desire to call out the military. There are safeguards in place. However, we believe and I understand it is the belief of the government that, to reassure the public that all matters or likely concerns have been ticked off on, it is appropriate for this matter to be referred to an appropriate Senate committee. The opposition certainly thinks that is desirable. We recognise that it is important to have these measures in place for the Olympics but, as a previous speaker indicated, these measures should not be seen as simply a short-term measure that can be sunsetted after the Olympics. They are in themselves important measures that are certainly required and the opposition certainly supports this legislation.

talk.start.para: âIt is good to see the bipartisan approach taken to this legislation, particularly on this Defence Legislation Amendment (Aid to Civilian Authorities) Bill 2000. I would like to remind the people of Australia that no government really owns the Defence Force. It is the Australian people that own the Defence Force. I think that is made very clear by this legislation and the bipartisan support for it. I am pleased to rise today to speak on a bill that will enable us to use the Australian Defence Force to assist with combating violence and terrorism and in other related public safety emergencies. Currently, there is an ability to call out the ADF but without an explicit accountability to the parliament. Obviously, the upcoming Sydney Olympics have encouraged the advancement of this bill, but the matter has been awaiting review for several years.

speech.para: As was stated last year, the deployment to East Timor was the most significant deployment of ADF personnel since the Second World War, in terms of its size and its contribution to Australia's security. The deployment to East Timor and its great success in restoring peace and security to the people of East Timor displayed the great contribution that our defence forces make to our country. The Defence contribution to the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games will be on a comparable scale to the deployment to East Timor. It is expected to be of the order of some 4,000 personnel. However, whilst the Defence support to the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games will be significant, in the best-case scenario it will be low key. Whilst the New South Wales Police Service will be responsible for overall security of the Games, they are working closely with Defence and other agencies to ensure that a high quality security response is provided to our Olympic Games. This planning does not indicate that the government is aware of a specific threat, but in planning for major international events it is normal to consider all possible eventualities and to plan and train accordingly.

I have been fortunate to see the result of the ADF training. Late last year I observed the Crocodile '99 exercises in Northern Queensland and I have to say I was very impressed. The standard of training was high. The innovation and attention to detail was extremely professional. I understand Operation Gold is the name given to the ADF support to the Sydney 2000 Games. It includes ADF support in two main areas: security tasks and general support. The general support will include drivers to assist in driving technical delegates and officials, ADF bands, support to ceremonial activities and venue managers. It is the security support that the ADF will provide to the games that is relevant to the bill we are discussing today. The security tasks to be undertaken by the ADF include a counter-terrorist response, operational search of venues and vehicles, bomb search, clearance divers and liaison officers.

As my colleague the member for Murray has explained, the Defence Legislation Amendment (Aid to Civilian Authorities) Bill 2000 proposes to amend the Defence Act 1903 to bring the framework for call-out of the Defence Force in law enforcement emergencies up to dateâand not before time. The bill provides a sound basis for the use of the Defence Force as a last resort in resolving such emergencies. Current legislation in the Defence Act 1903 concerning the procedures for call-out of the ADF to aid the civil power is deficient and certainly outdated. The purpose of this bill is to modernise this legislation in time to ensure that Australia has every possible option to ensure that the success of our games is not compromised. The concept behind this bill, therefore, is to modernise the procedures to be followed for call-out of the Defence Force, to set out safeguards including parliamentary supervision, and to specify the powers and obligations of the Defence Force when used to assist the police as a last resort in the counter-terrorist assault role and for related public safety tasks.

The bill will repeal section 51 of the Defence Act and add a new part. This new part will incorporate procedures for the use of the ADF to protect Commonwealth interests against violence in a state or territory, or at the request of a state or territory, as defined in section 119 of the Constitution. The Chief of the Defence Force must ensure that the Defence Force, while remaining under his command at all times, assists and cooperates with the police force of the state or territory. Members of the Defence Force will be able to exercise only such powers as are specified in the order, which in turn may only be from those powers that are set out in the bill. As far as is practicable, members of the Defence Force will not be able to exercise these powers unless requested to perform a task by the police of the state or territory.

This does not mean that the Defence Force will be taking over law enforcement in a scenario where they are called out. Rather, the legislation states unequivocally that the Defence Force will be there to assist the civilian authorities. Powers given to the Defence Force to, for example, rescue hostages or recapture premises or to detain suspects or search premises for dangerous itemsâall conceivably tasks that may be required of the ADF in a worst-case scenarioâmay only be exercised when a security area has been declared, and this declaration, the reasons for it and the powers conferred on the ADF must be made known to the public.

As my colleague the member for Murray has explained, when exercising the authorities set out in this bill, it will be an offence for a Defence Force member not to wear uniform and identification attached to the front of the uniform except where the absence of identification is caused by the act of someone else. It will also be an offence to obstruct a member performing these duties. If a member fails to comply with any obligation in relation to the exercise of these authorities they will be taken not to have been entitled to exercise them. The bill has no effect on uses or authorities of the Defence Force under other legislation and powers, such as customs, immigration and fisheries legislation.

This bill also preserves the current prohibition set out in section 51 of the Defence Act regarding the use of Defence Force elements in connection with industrial disputes. It attempts to provide for the changing nature of the terrorist threat, a threat that was not within contemplation when the Defence Act and its regulations were drafted almost 100 years ago. Today we must be on our guard against not only deadly military style conventional weapons but also the so-called weapons of mass destruction. When the sarin gas device was triggered in Tokyo, the lack of control and capability at the scene resulted in around 5,000 people, initially in contact with the toxic substance, fanning out around the city to contaminate other persons and medical facilities. While there is no expectation that we will ever confront such a threat, it would be irresponsible not to be prepared for it. This bill is therefore not only to add to the security measures that the government has for the Olympic Games but beyond that to our long-term ability to meet these types of security challenges. This form of support from the ADF is a less publicised role of our defence forces.

Many members here will be aware of the tremendous support that the ADF provides to the community through defence aid to the civil community, as opposed to civil power. We will all be aware of the rescues of lone sailors, Isabelle Autissier and Tony Bullimore, or the role that the ADF played in rescuing yachtsmen and yachtswomen during the tragic Sydney to Hobart yacht race in 1998. In this instance, assets from HMAS Albatross in my electorate were deployed to assist in the search and rescue operations. I can comment from my own experience on the professionalism and dedication of the ADF personnel carrying out these tasks. These are well-known examples of the capabilities and skills of our Defence Force. We have also seen the ADF contribute to the repair of homes in Sydney following last year's hailstorm and to countless other tasks, including medical evacuation, disaster relief and support to Customs and Immigration. Again, in my own electorate of Gilmore where large and intense bushfires are not uncommon, the local Defence Force personnel have left their bases to assist the Rural Fire Service and the community to protect our precious environment. I am confident that this bill will only add to the ability of our Defence Force to contribute to the safety and security of Australia.

The bill provides for the limited use of the Defence Force in the last resort where there is a significant threat to public safety or to deal with an armed terrorist attack, where the resources or capability of a state or territory may not be adequate. It does so without derogation from our cherished standards of justice and due process of the law. It provides safeguards and accountability. The tasks and authorities of the Defence Force are clearly spelled out so that both the public and the Defence Force know exactly what to expect. This also provides a sound basis upon which the Defence Force can train so that their responses and actions will be measured and appropriate.

The bill does not interfere with the jurisdiction of the courts to supervise the actions of the Defence Force. Members of the Defence Force remain accountable for their decisions to use force and for the lawfulness of their actions. However, the bill does provide Defence Force members with better protection for the action they may reasonably take. Finally, this bill enshrines fundamental democratic principles in the call-out process, as opposed to the current inadequate legislative framework, and emphasises and provides for the primacy of civilian control. In speaking of civilian control, for the first time we are currently seeking civilian input into our future defence policy.

The release yesterday of the government's public discussion paper on defence is to be applauded. Its aim, to involve the Australian community in determining our defence capabilities, means that it is timely to be discussing defence issues. As chair of the government defence and veterans' affairs committee, I led a delegation to Perth recently to investigate the capabilities of several defence bases and contractors in Western Australia. I cannot overemphasise the importance of our Australian citizens understanding the issues that face the ADF over the next 20 years. If we are to be in a position to assist our neighbouring countries to attain the security they desire, we must make some decisions very soon. The more people who can contribute their well-informed opinions and ideas, the better.

As the Prime Minister said yesterday, the discussion paper breaks new ground in involving the community in the defence debate. The highly successful and professional deployment of our Defence Force to East Timor means that public interest in defence is heightened. During my visit to East Timor earlier this year I saw, at first hand, the high regard in which our troops were held by the locals. This respect had been well earned through professional and humanitarian efforts on the part of our ADF personnel. I am sure that, if needed, our ADF personnel will provide the same top quality and dependable assistance in Sydney in the immediate future and to Australia in the long haul. The Defence Legislation Amendment (Aid to Civilian Authorities) Bill 2000 is a bill which is long overdue and I commend it to the House. I thank the opposition for supporting the bill and for taking a totally bipartisan approach.

talk.start.para: âMy understanding is that the Defence Legislation Amendment (Aid to Civilian Authorities) Bill 2000 lays out the proper procedure for the call-out of defence forces as a last resort in security emergencies. This updating of the Defence Act is driven by the Olympicsâand, I would hasten to remind members, the Paralympicsâand it is of course something for which there is a strong bipartisan approach. But it is not just the Olympics or the Paralympics that demand this type of legislation, because who can envisage what situations might occur in the future?

speech.para: I understand that the bill has been developed in conjunction with the agencies that would most likely be involved in a counter-terrorist call-out. I also understand that the bill provides that the call-out of the Defence Force can occur only as a last resort, where the resources of a state or territory are not sufficient to provide the best resolution of a situation. The sort of situation envisaged is one in which the use of specialised assault equipment and skills is required to deal with threats that might require the recovery of hostages, aircraft, ships, vehicles, offshore oil and gas installations, and buildings or other unforeseen areas of possible operation. Such situations could occur in an environment where chemical or biological substances have been used and where wholesale evacuation, the provision of cordons, seizing and making safe dangerous items, or a building search are required.

The bill provides for the Defence Force counter-terrorist assault role and authorises the use of necessary and reasonable force, including lethal force, for the purposes of rescuing hostages and recapturing both private and public property. Most importantly, it provides that the Defence Force remain under the control of the Chief of the Defence Force while ensuring that he, at all times, must assist and cooperate with state or Territory police. This is a most important, indeed crucial, part of any counter-terrorist action. I can see no circumstances where Defence control of Defence personnel should be passed to any other authority. That, however, places an extreme responsibility on all commanders to ensure that maximum and total cooperation exists at all times between Defence and civilian authorities.

The bill provides for the limited use of the Defence Force in last resort situations where there exists a significant threat to the safety of the public, or to deal with armed terrorist activity where the resources of a state or territory may not be sufficient to deal with the situation. Most importantly, this process spells out the tasks of the Defence Force. This is crucial for many reasons, including control on the ground, legal protection of Defence Force individuals, accountability and, most importantly, training purposes. The training that defence forces must undergo in counter-terrorism activities is extremely hazardous and dangerous. In many respects, it is more demanding and more dangerous than what many troops encounter in times of actual conflict, and I think we should bear that in mind.

Can members of this House envisage the degree of training that our Defence Force have had to undergo to achieve the high degree of professionalism that they pride themselves on? Can members envisage the dangerous, demanding and stressful regimes that members of the Defence Force must expose themselves to in order to achieve the precision and expertise that in times of terrorist action can make the difference between success or otherwise in an incident for which they are called out. The training separation from loved ones and the dedication to the protection of property and person are too often overlooked. The hazardous nature of Defence personnel training, particularly for the SAS and those who work closely with them, often only comes to light when there is a tragedy of the like of the Black Hawk disaster.

I certainly wish our Defence Force personnel well in their duties. They and their civilian counterparts will have a crucial role to play between now and the end of the year. We, like all Australians, would hope that there are no incidents associated with the Olympics or Paralympics. But, at the conclusion of the games, I hope that we as a nation pay as much tribute and give as much support and recognition to our Defence personnelâwho have worked at no small cost to themselves to meet whatever contingencies ariseâas that afforded to our recently returned Timor veterans, because these troops will indeed be the front line.

In conclusion, I must say that I have some serious concerns about the proper and adequate resourcing of our Defence Force under this government. The recent announcement that our defence forces are to be cut back by an additional 2,000 uniformed members is of serious concern and must put pressure on the Defence Force all the way down the line. In this context, I think it is unfair to blame the military for the delay in this type of legislation, as one previous speaker did. This type of legislation is the responsibility of the government and that is where the responsibility must rest. Having said that, I am very keen to reiterate the strong support that the opposition give to this bill, but I also want to reiterate the caveats put forward by the shadow defence spokesperson and the shadow Attorney-General who have given this bill their strong support. I also give my strong support to the bill. I certainly agree with other members who have spoken on it. We hope that what has been provided for in this legislation is never called upon.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I will take the opportunity to make a short contribution to the debate on the Defence Legislation Amendment (Aid to Civilian Authorities) Bill 2000. I am pleased that a number of government members have recognised that, as far as possible, the opposition has taken a bipartisan approach to the defence review. There could be no more important an area of government responsibility in this country than defence and it is always important that, as far as possible, we do take a bipartisan approach, both from the defence perspective and from the perspective that this is a very major area of government expenditure in this country.

speech.para: I want to briefly touch on a Defence facility in my own electorate of Hunterâthat is, of course, the Singleton infantry centre. That centre really underpins the health of both the economy of Singleton and the economy of the wider Upper Hunter community. It is a Defence facility that has had a dark cloud pushed over it on one or two occasions in the past. From my perspective, it is very important that the government move very quickly to reassure the residents of the Singleton and wider Upper Hunter communities, and indeed the Hunter community, that the review currently before the Australian community does not in any way threaten the ongoing viability or existence of that infantry centre. I know that I speak on behalf of all Hunter residents in making that point. It is vital that the facility remain in place. One has to say that once we start to talk about going below the critical 50,000 mass in our Defence personnel, some merger or aggregation is likely and, therefore, it is my great fear that that centre could again come under threat. I call upon the government to reassure the community that that is not the case.

talk.start.para: âI rise to support the Defence Legislation Amendment (Aid to Civilian Authorities) Bill 2000 because the area I represent in the Australian parliament has Australia's largest Defence base. Townsville-Thuringowa is known as the garrison city of the Commonwealth of Australia so many constituents of mine are very interested to see this legislation come in to the parliament this morning. Townsville is the home of the 3rd Brigade and, of course, 11 Brigade. In the 3rd Brigade we have Australia's ready deployment force. That is the group that responds at very short notice in times of emergency. We also have units like the 1st Battalion of the Royal Australian Regiment, the 2nd Battalion of the Royal Australian Regiment, 3 Brigade Administrative Support Battalion and 5 Aviation Regiment, which has been referred to in this debate todayâthat is the Black Hawk squadron. We have 3/4 Cavalry Regiment, 103 Signal Regiment, 4 Field Regiment, 3 Combat Engineers, 10/4 Support Battalionâin fact, you would almost think that we have the whole of the ADF with those kinds of units. It is certainly Australia's largest Defence base, along with RAAF Townsville, which serves an equally important purpose. I have to be very careful what I say in relation to RAAF Townsville because we have a lieutenant colonel with the Australian Army in the parliament this morning.

speech.para: In looking at this legislationâI was privileged to have a briefing and to examine the legislation before it came to the parliamentâI was very careful to make sure that it contained the checks and balances that are needed. I note that a number of speakers today have made the point that, indeed, this legislation basically puts into law nothing more, really, than is already in practice. I am pleased to see the bipartisan support the legislation is being given. I asked questions like: does this impact on people's civil liberties? Who can give the orders? What is the process of that? Are the orders time limited? What happens if there are Rambos around the place? Is there any change in how the defence forces may be used for things like industrial disputes? Of course, it all came up with a clean bill of health.

I make the point, and I think my colleagues would agree with me, that we have been trying to get this legislation in place for, perhaps, 20 years. There was certainly an attempt made in 1987 under the former Labor government and again in 1989, but they did not come to fruition. I guess it is sad that this legislation is not in place because it protects our members in the ADF in whatever they might do. It sets out the rules under which they can operate. It gives them a lawful base for doing what needs to be done in times of some kind of domestic violence in the country. It is very important that we have this in place, but it is sad that it has not been in place until now. I do know and understand what the urgency of this is. I know my colleagues know and understand that and I thank them for that support. I think this is a great step forward in what we are able to do.

I know that, certainly in times of domestic violence, 5 Aviation Regiment from Townsville is likely to be very closely involved. I pay tribute to the men and women of 5 AV, who have been training extraordinarily hard with other units from Perth to protect this country later this year if needed. I know that some of the residents of my city, just the odd one or two, had some complaints about the noise as helicopters were landing on the Civic Theatre, on top of the Taxation Office building, but it was training that needed to be done. It was in the national interest that our men and women in 5 Aviation Regiment trained with other regiments in their counter-terrorism role, and I know that they will be extraordinarily well prepared in the very unlikely event that they will be needed. I also know that they have been training in Sydney and, in the middle of all of this training, they did get a little bit of training in a place called Timor. Many of our helicopters went over there, and one of the interesting takeouts of that was that the more they flew the helicopters, the more reliable they became. It is interesting to know that that could happen, and there is a bit of a message in there for the ADF, I believe.

This is very good legislation. It certainly moves us forward very much. I am very pleased to be able to support it this morning in the Australian parliament on behalf of the several thousand men and women of Townsville and Thuringowa who are proud members of the Australian Defence Force.

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to speak on the Defence Legislation Amendment (Aid to Civilian Authorities) Bill 2000. Of course it is being supported by the opposition. The impetus for this bill is long standing. It really goes back to 1978, with the Hilton Hotel bombing in Sydney during the CHOGM meeting. I guess it reflects poorly on governments on both sides that we have not responded earlier to that situation. The urgency now is because of the Olympics.

speech.para: I think every member in this chamber would hope that this legislation will never be required to be usedâthat is, that there is never a need to call out the ADF to help the police in a terrorist situation. Once upon a time we would have been fairly confident that that would not be the case. Now we are probably a little less confident, but I sincerely hope that it does not come to pass.

There was a great deal of media coverage of the police and the ADF practising counter-terrorism in relation to the Olympic Games. I apologise for bringing a personal complaint to you and to the House, Mr Deputy Speaker, but the softball facilities for the Olympics, which were a venue for practising counter-terrorism, are located in my electorate. I regret to say that $100,000 worth of damage has occurred. This is not actually the source of my complaint. I have been approached by a number of constituents who have said that there is a particularly ugly building in my electorateâthe former Astro Cinema, which is no longer usedâand why wasn't I forthcoming in assisting our Defence and counter-terrorism forces by offering that building as a practice ground. So could I make the plea to the learned departmental officers in the advisers box that if they are contemplating any more practices, could we have a dialogue and I will see what I can do about the former Astro Cinema site in Mount Druitt.

This is a bill about calling out Defence. I would not want to reflect on the honourable member for Herbert, but I can suggest to him a useful fundraiser. He has a large number of Defence personnel in his electorate.

talk.start.para: âTwo dollars for coffee.

âNot $2 for coffee, although I understand the member for Eden-Monaro has pioneered that particular approach amongst pensioners. My suggestion is to run a guessing competition on when the government will bring in legislation to give effect to the policy that they have already announced; that is, the ability to call out the reserves in other than the defence of Australia. This was announced quite some time ago by the minister. Although we have this important bit of legislation, it has nothing to do with that announced policy. It seems to me to be quite ironic, at a time when we are going to be busily consulting with the Australian people, that the government has been unable to give legislative effect to its announced intention.

speech.para: The unit that would be primarily involved in counter-terrorism would be our SAS. As members of the public, we do not always get to hear about their good deeds and their strengths, which are considerable, both in counter-terrorism and in other operations. But I might say that it is conceivableâif this legislation passes, and surely it willâthat there may be some reserves involved. I can imagine a scenario where the SAS may be involved and, to make up numbers, a reserve unit of commandos may be called on. Perhaps the parliamentary secretary can help me. I would be very interested to know, and clearly they must be covered under this legislation, whether in such an eventuality that commandos were utilised, would they be merely on commando pay or reserve pay? Would they be on full-time pay? What would be the length and duration of that full-time commitment? I would be very interested in that. If they were going to be paid extra emoluments or allowances, would they, like the 600 reserves that went to East Timor, lag behind everyone in the regular forces? Has the government thought this situation through?

I do not want to give the impression that I am quibbling about this legislationâit is important, and it rectifies a great deal of uncertainty. I notice that there are some safeguards: the state does have to request assistance; there must be a defined area of operations; there must be a decision by the Prime Minister, the Attorney-General and the Minister for Defence; and an order must be signed off by the Governor-General to effect this call-out. These are important issues. There needs to be a degree of accountability, like all matters involved in the breadth and width of national government, and there is certainly a greater degree of accountability in these arrangements. Successive governments, of course, have had a cabinet national security subcommittee, and this is hardly radical or new, but in the light of this bill, and in the light of so much uncertainty in our environment, I repeat a call made by the former shadow minister, Arch Bevis, that the time is rapidly coming where we need to have a national security council made up of not only ministers and public servants but also some outside specialists. The benefit of this primarily is that, in issues of national security, you will more readily get a whole of government approach to it. Time is ticking away and I predict with a degree of confidence that not before too long we will see this major change in our national security arrangements.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you might say it is a bit of nitpickingâI will not apologise for that; I do not think it is nitpickingâbut it is most unfortunate that the bill, and the things that accompany the bill, talk about these legislative changes meeting the needs of domestic violence. When people talk about domestic violence these daysâand forgive me, because I am involved in family lawâwe normally associate that with the violence that occurs in homes. It is a little insensitive of the government to use the words `domestic violence'. There is a whole range of words that could have been usedâdomestic disorder, domestic unrest or a severe terrorist situation. Mr Deputy Speaker, if you feel that I am rebuking the parliamentary secretary at the table, or even of being bold enough to rebuke the advisers or those sitting in the advisers box, so be it, but I do think it was insensitive. It might have been a tad better had other words been chosen.

My time is limited, I regret to say. The opposition supports this measure, but there is only one day left in the legislative calendar for this to be debated, and that is tomorrow. You could hardly say that the government has left itself with a lot of leeway on this measure. After all, the Olympics have been a fairly predictable event for some time. Be that as it may, the opposition supports this change, and one can only hope that the bill gets a swift passage in the Senate.

I will finish on this note: I hope the Minister for Defence will bring further legislation into this parliament, perhaps calling out the reserves, and that he will be prepared to make a number of ministerial statements. It is an absolute scandal that the launch of a green paper that allegedly makes a huge change to the way we approach defence matters does not merit a ministerial statement. The opposition has not been given the opportunity to adopt a bipartisan approach, which in Defence matters we try to do. I compliment the government. When we have been in government, we have certainly tried to be bipartisan, but the government has to actually give us some opportunities, both in policy terms and in debating terms. The shadow minister has not had an opportunity to comment in the Hansard about that, and there are a number of members around who may be involved in their party's defence committee or the parliamentary committees who would be interested in a statement of such alleged significance and would want to contribute and to participate.

It is fair enough to say that we have all gloried in the success of East TimorâGeneral Cosgrove and all of those thousands of men and women in the ADF who participated over thereâbut where was the debate in this chamber about the lessons learned in East Timor? None at all. There have been severe problemsâvery severe problems. Where is the minister's statement? We know there are two cabinet submissions, but where is the ministerial statement about how the minister sees the reserves fitting into the structure of the Army? How does the government see that?
